title: 107_hr809
content: The Act may be cited as the "Antitrust Technical Corrections Act of 2001" and includes amendments. The Antitrust Technical Corrections Act of 2001 repeals the Act of March 3, 1913 and amends the Panama Canal Act and Sherman Act to address monopolization and trade practices. The Wilson Tariff Act is amended to include penalties for violations, with fines up to $10,000,000 for corporations and $350,000 for individuals, along with possible imprisonment for up to three years. The Antitrust Technical Corrections Act of 2001 repeals the Act of March 3, 1913 and makes amendments to the Panama Canal Act and Sherman Act regarding monopolization and trade practices. The Clayton Act, Federal Trade Commission Act, Packers and Stockyards Act, and Atomic Energy Act are all amended to change the reference of "seventy-seven" to "seventy-six". The Deep Seabed Hard Mineral Resources Act is amended to change the reference from "77" to "76". The Clayton Act is also amended to redesignate section 27 as section 28. The Year 2000 Information and Readiness Disclosure Act is amended to include a period after "failure". The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to clarify that nothing in the Act modifies or supersedes certain provisions. The Deep Seabed Hard Mineral Resources Act is amended to refer to "antitrust laws" instead of specific sections. The Clayton Act is also amended to replace references to "the foregoing Acts" with "antitrust laws". Additionally, subsection (c) clarifies that certain provisions do not apply to applications for antitrust laws. The subsection exempts pending or new applications for a license to construct or operate a utilization facility under specific sections from certain provisions. It does not impact the Commission's authority to enforce antitrust conditions in licenses issued before the enactment of the subsection. SEC. 3 of the Act states that the Act and its amendments will take effect on the enactment date. Section 2(a) applies to pending cases, while the amendments in subsections (b), (c), and (d) of section 2 apply to cases started after the enactment date.
